section.title: going to (future plans)
section.sectiontitle: Use going to to talk about intentions or plans (an intention is something you have already decided to do).
section.text1: A: Are you going to see Sally this week?
section.text1a: B: I don't know. I'm going to phone her this afternoon.
section.text2a: We're going to the swimming pool this afternoon.
section.sectiontitle2: Form sentences with: the subject + the verb to be + going to + verb. Use contractions.
section.text3: I am going to see my parents on Saturday.
section.text3a: I'm going to see my parents on Saturday.
section.text4: She is not going to (go to) the cinema on Sunday.
section.text4a: She's not going to (go to) the cinema on Sunday.

section.title: going to (future plans)
section.sectiontitle: To make questions put the auxiliary verb to be before the subject. Use the auxiliary verb to be in short answers.
section.text1: You are going to see your parents at the weekend.
section.text1a: A: Are you going to see your parents at the weekend? B: Yes, I am.
section.text2: She is going to stay with us.
section.text2a: A: Is she going to stay with us? B: No, she isn't.
section.sectiontitle2: We often use future time expressions with going to, for example this afternoon, tonight, tomorrow, next week.
section.text3a: We're going to have a party tomorrow.
section.text4a: They're going to visit the museum this afternoon.
